title: Design leaders need to jam with their teams
text:
Design leaders need to jam with their teams

How business management killed craft apprenticeship

Victor Wooten is my all-time favorite bassist. But, itâ€™s not only because of his amazing playing skills. Itâ€™s also his philosophy of teachingÂ music.

He runs music camps where complete beginners are invited to come jam with him, the professional musician. His philosophy is simple: there are no wrong notes, no punishment or judgement for misfit notes. What mattersâ€¦is what you do after you play them. Wooten points out that this is how babies learn language. Theyâ€™re allowed to â€œjamâ€ with professionals from day one. It would be absurd if we made children practice grammar alone until they were fluent enough to speak with adults. But, thatâ€™s typically how music is taught, and it takes tooÂ long.

Iâ€™ve been playing bass for quite a few years and Wootenâ€™s approach resonates with how I actually learned the most. Sure books and courses are helpful, but itâ€™s jamming with other people (better than me), watching how they think in real time, deciding when to hold back, when to step forward, how to recover when something doesnâ€™t land. Thatâ€™s where a lot of the breakthroughs happen. And, thatâ€™s what Cal Newport calls career capital: the skills you build by working next to people who already have them. Reading about the skills are helpful, but you need to be â€œin the room jammingâ€ with people to really get the fullÂ effect.

And thatâ€™s exactly what weâ€™ve stopped doing inÂ design.

The False Binary Weâ€™veÂ Created

When you move from individual contributor to design leader, the fear of micromanagement sets in. Youâ€™re told â€œdonâ€™t dictate pixelsâ€ and â€œdonâ€™t hover over your teamâ€™s shouldersâ€. Youâ€™re told to stay strategic. The message is clear: good managers stay out of the details. And for good reason: nobody wants a boss who controls every decision and undermines their teamâ€™s autonomy. So design leaders internalize this rule and step back from craft entirely.

Youâ€™re faced with twoÂ choices:

  • The â€œWrongâ€ One: Stay hands-on with craft, but risk micromanaging, dictating pixels, and undercutting teamÂ autonomy
  • The â€œRightâ€ One: Stay strategic and high-level, stay out of their work, leave craft to the individual contributors

Management in the design industry has overwhelmingly chosen to stay out of craft. Design leaders believe â€œGood managers donâ€™t get sucked into the detailsâ€ or â€œI empower my team by staying high level.â€ Sounds right. Sounds like good management.

If thatâ€™s the â€œrightâ€ decision, then why is our industry struggling so much? Why do junior designers fail to grow into fully-fledged seniors? Nobodyâ€™s taught these younger designers to think like designers. To reason through problems. To wrestle with complexity the way experienced designers do. We blame â€œoutsideâ€ forces like automation, shrinking budgets, and organizational shifts that prioritize speed. But I think weâ€™re missing a systemic cause: weâ€™ve dismantled the apprenticeship model from bothÂ ends.

The Dismantling of Apprenticeship

To understand how we got here, we need to look at designâ€™s journey of professionalization. Design schools have existed since the 1870sâ€Šâ€”â€ŠRISD, Pratt, Parsonsâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut they operated on apprenticeship principles. You learned in studios under master teachers. When you graduated, you joined design agencies and continued learning the same way: working alongside senior designers, watching how they solved problems, gradually taking on more responsibility. Through the 60s, 70s, and 80s, this was just how you learned theÂ craft.

Then came the web. In the 2000s, digital design was still craft-heavyâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe were people who made things look nice, who skinned websites. We wanted a seat at the table, to weigh in on decisions that impacted our work. So we embraced design thinking, user-centered design, and strategic frameworks. This was necessary. Software was getting complex, and design needed a voice beyond aesthetics. But we over-corrected.

As Jenny Wen pointed out in her talk â€œCraft is Counter-Intuitive,â€ we tilted so far toward strategy that craft started to feel less important. Portfolios became filled with diagrams and journey maps, maybe one screen mockup. Design systems made our work modular and efficient, but also boring and predictable. We automated the artistry out of our own jobs. And when designers moved into leadership, they followed modern management principlesâ€Šâ€”â€Šprinciples designed for business and tech, not craft-based disciplines. The advice was clear: stay strategic, donâ€™t micromanage, empower through delegation. So design leaders withdrew from craft entirely. â€œStay out of the workâ€ became the hallmark of good management, even though design is a craft that requires apprenticeship.

At the same time, we industrialized design education. Bootcamps promised to turn people into designers in twelve weeks. They taught frameworks, processes, and deliverablesâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut they couldnâ€™t teach the apprenticeship model because they didnâ€™t have it themselves. Students went from bootcamp curricula to design systems, never experiencing what itâ€™s like to jam with someone whoâ€™s been doing this forÂ years.

What Juniors ActuallyÂ Need

But we need to get back to a Victor Wooten approach. You donâ€™t learn to speak by practicing alone until youâ€™re fluent or reading in books. You donâ€™t learn jazz by studying theory in isolation. You learn by doing it next to people who already know how. The â€œjammingâ€ model creates a safe space to make mistakes. It puts you close to people who know what theyâ€™re doing, so you can watch how they think. You learn when to lead, when to follow, when to take risks. You see the quiet corners of practice, not just the outcome. You watch someone hit a dead end, figure out whatâ€™s not working, and iterate toward something better.

You learn by doing it next to people who already knowÂ how.

This is what our industry desperately needs. This is what junior designers need. They need to jam with people whoâ€™ve been doing this for years. They need to see how you think through design problems, watch you work through solutions in real time, and feel the difference between an acceptable solution and a great one. You canâ€™t learn this from tutorials or design system documentation or other junior designers. Thatâ€™s like babies only talking to other babies. Yet this is exactly where weâ€™ve leftÂ them.

What Jamming Looks Like inÂ Practice

Jenny Wen, Design Lead at Anthropic and former Director of Design at Figma, shows what the third way looks like. In her talk, she challenges the â€œstay out of the workâ€ rule directly. She notes that craft-focused companies are increasingly looking for leaders who are hands-on, who can help teams do great work, who can get into the details and push their teams to be better. Her critical insight: â€œIf your team is already really great at craft or already really senior, you believe that you can make them even better at it. I think thatâ€™s the most empowering thing you can give yourÂ team.â€

What does she actuallyÂ do?

  • Pairs directly with designers on challenging work. When the Figma Slides product icon had too many stakeholders and too many opinions, she sat down with the designer and they pushed pixels together to arrive at the final design. Then she helped defend that decision.
  • Gives detailed design feedback, not just about strategy and problems, but about border radius and hierarchy, because these details matter to support the overarching strategy.
  • Riffs on designs, hopping into files and creating her own versions, making it clear to her team that these are explorations, not directives. They donâ€™t have to choose herÂ option.
  • Concepts work herself to help drive direction and push teams to be more ambitious. When sheâ€™s managing, sheâ€™s rarely designing, but when it would help, she doesnâ€™t holdÂ back.

The foundation of all of this is trust. Everything she does comes from â€œa place of trust,â€ as she puts it. Decisions still belong to the designer. Sheâ€™s helping as a teammate, not asserting authority. This is jamming: working together on craft, showing how you think instead of dictating what to do. Youâ€™re getting close without taking over. Youâ€™re hands-on without controlling. Thatâ€™s the distinction weÂ missed.

Youâ€™re getting close without taking over. Youâ€™re hands-on without controlling.

Iâ€™ve been doing exactly what Jenny describes for years. Pairing with designers, pushing pixels together, giving detailed craft feedback. But I did it quietly, almost like I was breaking the rules, because I knew as a manager â€œI wasnâ€™t supposed to.â€ Iâ€™d tell myself I was just â€œhelping outâ€ rather than admitting what it really wasâ€Šâ€”â€Šteaching. Jennyâ€™s talk was freeing. It gave me permission to stop apologizing for being hands-on withÂ craft.

This shift is already happening whether you choose it or not. Organizations are flattening, and managers are being asked to be more hands-on. The tools our teams use are more powerful than ever, and the software people love is increasingly defined by its craft. Design needs different leadership now.

What This Requires ofÂ You

This requires some nuance. Not all leaders need design backgrounds; team composition often needs other skills. And this isnâ€™t about doing all the craft yourself or dictating solutions. Itâ€™s about being intentional and careful about when you jump in. Know when your presence helps and when it gets in the way. You need to recognize the difference between helping and controlling. Build trust so your team knows what youâ€™re doing. Be vulnerable enough to show your dead ends, not just your successes. Wootenâ€™s â€œno wrong notesâ€ philosophy doesnâ€™t mean there are no standards. Youâ€™re creating safety to learn and explore, not accepting mediocrity.

Empower people by working close to them, not by staying out. Treat craft like part of your job is teaching, not just something you personally like. Recognize that hands-on with trust is jamming, not micromanagement.

How to Start Jamming with YourÂ Team

Practically, this looks different for everyÂ team:

  • Protect time for pairing sessions: maybe Friday afternoons are sacred for working through hard problemsÂ together
  • Give feedback on the details that matter: border radius, hierarchy, type scale, not just strategy andÂ flows
  • Riff on designs in shared files the way Jenny does: make it clear these are options to explore, not mandates toÂ follow
  • Model your thinking process, including the dead ends, not just the polished solutions

What ever you do, just remember: youâ€™re creating opportunities toÂ jam.

The Jam Session IsÂ Waiting

If youâ€™re a design leader, I want to encourage you to get back in the room. Your team needs to jam with you. If youâ€™re hiring design leaders, look for people who can make the work better, not just manage the process. If youâ€™re a junior designer, get close to people who know what theyâ€™re doing. Find your jam session. Thatâ€™s where the learningÂ happens.

Babies donâ€™t wait until theyâ€™re fluent to speak with adults. Musicians donâ€™t wait until theyâ€™re perfect to play with the band. Designers shouldnâ€™t have to wait until theyâ€™re senior to work alongside masters. The jam session is where learning happens, and your team is waiting for you to showÂ up.

title: A sharp tool can still ruin the cut
text:
A sharp tool can still ruin the cut

When AI answers before you understand.

I never decided to go all in on AI, it just kept showingÂ up.

At first, in small, practical ways. Generating content for design mocks or writing simple scripts to automate boring tasks. I even built a Figma plugin to easily rename all the icons in our icon library, to avoid the repetitive work, but also because I was curious if I could make itÂ work.

One thing led to another. I started playing around and started finding excuses to explore. I built an iOS app to keep track of daily exercise, started playing with V0 and Lovable to quickly brainstorm and generate rough design directions.

Then the play started to become serious, when I took a stab at shipping real production PRs into the Shopify admin, and even more serious after I joined the SidekickÂ team.

I wasnâ€™t forced. I didnâ€™t plan it. It was just inevitable.

When you get a sharp knife, you donâ€™t keep cutting with the blunt one.
But somewhere along the way, I started noticing that this knife couldÂ slip.

From wandering toÂ answers

Early on I changed how I approach research online. I stopped defaulting to Google search and started relying more on Perplexity, and other similarÂ tools.

On paper, itâ€™s an obvious upgrade. Direct answers, cleaner summaries, fewer tabs open, and much less noise. But something subtle disappeared in theÂ process.

No more random blog posts from 2010, fewer half-relevant Reddit rabbit holes. Almost nothing that pulled me somewhere unexpected.

I stopped wandering, I started extracting.

Super efficient, but over time, that efficiency started to shape how I thought. I was moving faster towards answers, but along narrower paths. Ideas felt more predictable, and I was less surprised by where I ended up. The work converged quickly, sometimes tooÂ quickly.

Design almost never benefits from straight lines. Some ideas only show up when you take the long way around, when you donâ€™t quite know what youâ€™re looking for yet. When thereâ€™s room for detours, dead ends, side-quests, and a bit of adventure.

Thatâ€™s when I started noticing how much the tools were quietly changing where my attention went.

When speed feels like understanding

The popular narrative is that AI makes people ten times faster. Thatâ€™s not false, but itâ€™s missing something important.

Speed always mattered in design, because it enables you to explore more options, learn sooner, and iterate your ways towards something better. Which is super valuable when you know what youâ€™re aimingÂ for.

What changed with AI wasnâ€™t that reality, itâ€™s the fact that now I can do things that I wouldnâ€™t have attempted atÂ all.

Itâ€™s not just making me explore more ideas faster, prototype thoughts sooner. Itâ€™s also giving the capability to touch code areas that I used to treat as off-limits, to ship production PRs. Crossing boundaries that previously felt like someone elseâ€™sÂ job.

This shift is real, and itâ€™s empowering.

But thereâ€™s a catch, when something becomes easy or possible, it can feel understood. The act of doing replaces the work of learning. I could change things confidently, quickly, and convincingly, and in the process mistake that fluency for comprehension.

This is where the delusion creeps in. AI makes you believe youâ€™re quickly unlocking new capabilities before you actually earn the right to do so. You believe that because you can change something easily, you understand it.

That confusion between ease and understanding showed up for me very concretely when I started shipping production code. I tried to start small, a spacing fix. Something contained, just visual polish. Turns out to be one of the hardest things I could have picked, according to an engineer that reviewed myÂ PR.

The spacing issue wasnâ€™t local, it was the result of deeper inconsistencies across shared components. I only understood that after that very patient engineer walked me through the system and its dependencies.

Shipping production software inside a large organization still has gravity. There are stakeholder, reviews, guardrails, dependencies, and real consequences. No amount of prompting turns that into a free-for-all, and thatâ€™s a goodÂ thing.

Ultimatly, after properly understanding the problem we didnâ€™t just fix the symptom, we fixed the core problem. But when I asked Claude (in Cursor) to fix the issue, it did. Quickly and bluntly. It ignored system constraints, because it didnâ€™t know they existed, and I didnâ€™t know anyÂ better.

Confidence without context is a delusion. Being able to make something with AI isnâ€™t the same as understanding what youâ€™reÂ making.

When the tool sets the direction

Most conversations about AI in design drift quickly toward how people are using it. One-shot prompts, workflows, tool stacks, prototype hacks. The tool becomes theÂ story.

â€œHow did you make this?â€ quietly replaces a more important question: â€œWhat were you trying to accomplish, andÂ why?â€

That shift matters, because when the how comes too early, it starts shaping the outcome. You optimize for what the tool is good at, and adjust the problem to fit the workflow.

The demos look technically impressive and you get results quickly. It feels like magic, but strong design direction doesnâ€™t come from execution tricks. It comes fromÂ intent.

When the how leads, quality follows the path with least resistance, not necessarily the one worthÂ taking.

Earlier this year I was tasked to create an illustration style with AI.
I explored several directions that were heavily shaped by AIâ€™s strengths and limitations at the time. The results were interesting, and I would go as far as saying a couple directions were an improvement over what we had, but they didnâ€™t stand on theirÂ own.

The direction couldnâ€™t convincingly last over time, and even though we got really close to shipping it, a key stakeholder put a pause in the project, and rightfully so.

That failure wasnâ€™t because AI was bad at illustration, it was because I let the tool define directions before an idea had earned its shape. Also the fact that it as an AI generated style started to matter more than whether the actual direction.

The problem wasnâ€™t usefulness, it wasÂ timing.

I feel this a lot when I try to prototype genuinely new ideas withÂ AI.

I start refining prompts, then refining the prompt that refines the prompt. I sketch something in Figma, just to explain what I mean. Suddenly, Iâ€™m no longer exploring the problem space, Iâ€™m negotiating with a probabilistic system.

The focus shifts. Iâ€™m not designing the idea anymore, Iâ€™m designing for theÂ tool.

What gets pushedÂ aside

AI trains impatience. When it doesnâ€™t get things right fast enough, I feel friction. And that friction shows up precisely where slowness actuallyÂ matters.

A pencil and paper, or a blank Figma canvas, let me dump ideas out of my head without having to explain myself. I can contradict myself, I can be sloppy, I can discover the problem while working onÂ it.

AI demands certainty much earlier, it struggles when the input is fuzzy, novel or still forming. When constraints need to bend and evolve, instead of locking everything tooÂ soon.

Those are exactly the moments where design needs space to reflect, not quick answers. Design starts with ambiguity, not clarity. With ideas that are still fragile and half-formed. With thoughts that donâ€™t quite line upÂ yet.

Designers need time toÂ wonder.

Time to poke ideas without knowing where theyâ€™ll land. Time to follow threads that might go somewhere. Time to sit with something unresolved long enough for it to surpriseÂ you.

That space used to exist more naturally, now itâ€™s getting compressed.

When answers arrive too early, they create a sense of progress, but lack depth. You move forward, but not inwards. You lock in the first thing that makes sense, because it arrivedÂ quickly.

Reflection doesnâ€™t vanish on its own, it gets pushed aside. If you donâ€™t protect it, it doesnâ€™tÂ survive.

Judgement is the real multiplier

The same tools in the hands of different designers donâ€™t produce similar results. They amplify whatâ€™s already there.
You donâ€™t get taste, judgement, context, and design sensitivity forÂ free.

AI doesnâ€™t level the field, it widens the gap.
Because it doesnâ€™t replace judgement, it leans onÂ it.

A weak designer doesnâ€™t suddenly produce great work with better tools. They just produce mediocre work faster. A strong designer uses the same tools very differently. They explore more directions, but they also discard aggressively. They recognize whatâ€™s obvious and push pastÂ it.

The tool augments you, not design in the abstract. So what you bring to the table as a designer actually matters even moreÂ now.

I felt this clearly while preparing a workshop earlier this year. I started by dumping everything out of my head. Ideas, doubts, half-formed thoughts. Only after that I used ChatGPT to explore formats, exercises, and ways to structure my sessions.

It was incredibly helpful, and a speed boost. But only because I already had a sense of direction. I still had to decide what to keep, what to ignore, and what actually felt like me, because ultimately I need to feel comfortable standing in front of people and ownÂ it.

Iâ€™ve noticed this pattern repeat. Once something exists, like a sketch or rough idea, AI can be a helpful partner to expand your options, challenge assumptions, and suggest variations.

Itâ€™s great at reacting to something concrete, but doesnâ€™t do it pro-actively.
AI is not curious, itâ€™s optimized to continue your thoughts, not to come up with new ones. So if you use it as a starting point, thatâ€™s where you dilute yourÂ intent.

What gets lost when everything feels likeÂ magic

Iâ€™m happy to hand off repetitive busy work to AI. The kind of effort that burns time without building judgement. Removing that toils is a real win, especially because it clearsÂ space.

But some struggles are worthÂ keeping.

AI is extremely good at multiplying output, but learning doesnâ€™t compound just because you did more things. It compounds when you compare, discard, and understand why one direction is better thanÂ another.

Iterating through bad ideas. Refining a design until it finally feels right. Figuring out how to explain your thinking to other people. Being wrong and having to course-correct. Sitting with uncertainty longer than is comfortable. These moments may not look efficient, but they are formative. Thatâ€™s where taste comesÂ from.

Without these loops, experience doesnâ€™t compound. It flattens.
Itâ€™s like trying to learn how to draw by tracing pictures. Youâ€™re going to get a decent result faster, but youâ€™re not actually learning.

A lot of people talk about design replacing juniors, and paint a world where a single super senior designer, with the right tools, can do everything. Strategy, exploration, execution, polish. Basically, theyâ€™re the maestro, and they play all the instruments. Thatâ€™s a lot to carryÂ alone.

What this misses, is the fact that junior designers arenâ€™t a tool.
They donâ€™t just execute. They question decisions and propose alternatives. They bring a unique perspective, sometimes naive, that makes the work better. Theyâ€™re not invested in obeying and pleasing you, and just doing what theyâ€™reÂ told.

When AI is your only partner, the expectation flips. Itâ€™s all onÂ you.

Even if youâ€™re lucky to have colleagues around, youâ€™ll notice that most feedback changes when people arenâ€™t actively working on the same problem. You get reactions instead of debate. Validation instead of pushback.

Creativity gets quieter, more internal.

Human friction still matters. Not just for the sake of quality and innovation, but to keep you from fooling yourself.

Design matters moreÂ now

Design doesnâ€™t disappear because systems can generate things. If nothing else, designers still have to shape these systemâ€™s interactions, mental models, build trust and failureÂ modes.

The chat interface is the beginning, not the end. Theyâ€™re a convenient starting point, but not a natural destination. Weâ€™re already seeing that evolution is starting to happen with tools like Cursor introducing mixing conversation with direct manipulation. That feels like an early signal, not a finishedÂ answer.

Working on Sidekick has made especially clear to me how young and rudimentar these tools still are. A lot of their behaviour is still evolving, and the potential isÂ immense.

Recently, I worked on our app-generation baseline prompt and design guidance, where I had to decide what the model should optimize for, and just as importantly, what it shouldÂ avoid.

This kind of work doesnâ€™t look like traditional feature design. Itâ€™s closer to shaping behaviour, explaining intent, providing examples, anticipating needs and misuse. Designing guardrails without locking everything downâ€¦ sounds a lot like design systems, doesnâ€™tÂ it?

The difference now, is that we have a real opportunity to make these tools feel more human. To meet people where they are, instead of forcing everyone through a single predefined flow, or pre-baked set of components.

Interfaces donâ€™t have to be static anymore, they can adapt to context, intent, and experience. But that space needs to be thoroughly explored.

It needs design. It needs designers to wander, to tinker, and more importanly, to haveÂ fun.

Where the cutÂ happens

None of what I said above means AI doesnâ€™t belong in earlyÂ design.

AI has meaningfully changed how I work. It helps me explore directions faster, summarize large contexts, bridge into code, and offload repetitive work so I can spend energy where it actuallyÂ matters.

Whatâ€™s important is not what AI can do, itâ€™s what I do with it.
Used too early, it collapses uncertainty before ideas have earned their shape. User a bit later, it becomes a powerful partner, reacting to intent instead of definingÂ it.

This isnâ€™t a question of AIâ€™s capability, itâ€™s a question of YOUR capability andÂ timing.

This reminds me of the first Japanese chefâ€™s knife I ever bought.
It looked beautiful. Perfect balance and incredibly sharp. It cut through almost everything with no effortâ€¦ including me.

One of the first things I did with it was slice my hand. The knife went through my skin with no resistance. I still have theÂ scar.

The knife wasnâ€™t the problem, it was doing exactly what it was designed to do. I just wasnâ€™t ready to handleÂ it.

AI feels powerful, easy to use, and only getting sharper. If youâ€™re not careful, it lets you move so fast that you skip the moments where attention and judgment matterÂ most.

So the question isnâ€™t if AI is sharp enough for you to use it.
The real question is whether youâ€™re paying enough attention to where and when youâ€™reÂ cutting.

title: A product managerâ€™s 48 reflections on 2025
text:
A product managerâ€™s 48 reflections on 2025

and why Iâ€™ve been making Bob Dylan songs about Sonic theÂ Hedgehog

In 2025, AI stopped feeling like just a tool to me and started to feel more like aÂ mirror.

This thought really struck me while generating music with Suno AI. Through the process of creating, I was channelling my raw emotion, emotions I hadnâ€™t realised I was even dealing with at the time. Is this how musicians feel when writingÂ songs?

This AI tool, like so many Iâ€™ve used this year, did not help reflect just my productivity, but also showed me my intentions, my taste, and sometimes even my nostalgia. In a way, the songs I was generating were more truthful about what was happening in my life than I was willing toÂ admit.

Hell, I was producing so many songs at one point that they started subtly referencing one another with a lyric here and there, creating my own mini music universe. I made a Bob Dylan-style narrative about Sonic from the comic, weaving in philosophical concepts. I remixed If Youâ€™re Strong You Can Fly from Sonic CD. I turned classic poems into music: The Tyger and TheÂ Raven.

I appreciate these experiments because they prompt me to critically examine whether AI-generated artefacts are inherently more detached from us as creators. Because this raises important questions about the nature of ownership in collaborative creation with AI. While it is possible to use AI while still maintaining ownership of the resulting ideas, this requires oneâ€™s ability to articulate, defend, and integrate them into oneâ€™s own conceptual framework. Ultimately, if we fail to maintain active engagement with the creative process and merely delegate tasks to AI without reflection, there is a risk that delegation becomes abdication of responsibility and authorship.

Where weâ€™reÂ heading

I think weâ€™re at an inflexion point for product management and knowledge work more broadly. The tools we have now enable us to operate at a scale and speed that was unimaginable even two years ago. But that acceleration comes with a cost: weâ€™re less practised at the slow, deliberate thinking that leads toÂ insight.

In the field of product management, I have long suspected that the future belongs to generalists, and Iâ€™ve never been more sure of that. Those who can think and do, who understand engineering, data science, UX, marketing, and sales deeply enough to prototype, test models, run discovery, and build strategies that excite teams will be the most successful. The single-domain specialist is increasingly aÂ relic.

The most important thing we can do is maintain our attention, take accountability for our actions and deliverables, and resist the weaponisation of our curiosity. Thatâ€™s the workÂ ahead.

From tarot to moon ceremonies

Last year, I joked about using tarot cards for sprint planning. This year, Iâ€™ve built on that theme. 2025 was the year I got introduced to moon ceremonies and magic stones. I understand many will read that and think Iâ€™ve gone potty, but hear meÂ out.

Like tarot, I donâ€™t really believe these things have any inherent power, but they are useful for reflection by forcing you to recognise where you are right now and set an intention. But whatâ€™s surprised me: these silly ceremonies are very engaging. Friends, family, even colleagues: people WANT to be involved in the silly gathering. Curiosity, novelty, disgust, whatever it is, itâ€™s just fun. There is something about putting people in a scenario where we can all share in the collective chaos of the universe and support each other through whatever insights we find. Friendship is not natural. It needs work because to be human is to be an animal that needs witnesses.

Anyway, those are just the highlights. Below are more reflections that gave me pause this year. Dive in, and I hope they inspire and invoke thoughts that set you up for a greatÂ 2026.

The Reflections

On debate and changingÂ minds:

  1. The best way to resolve a conflict or debate is to make the argument of your opponent better than they could. You literally have to make a better version of their argument, state it back to them, then ask, â€œDid I miss anything?â€ That clarity of understanding is the foundation for any possible change of mind for all parties involved, including ourselves.
  2. Changing somebodyâ€™s mind is one of the hardest things to achieve, and aggressive approaches tend to backfire. There is one thing that works, though: show curiosity. Be interested in what they are saying and try to understand why they think that way. This will provoke a considerably more open-minded response from others. Curiosity: the same thing social media weaponises against us, but when genuinely deployed in conversation, becomes one of our most powerful tools for connection.
  3. When debating, people tend to prefer the position of those who donâ€™t really hold one of their own. LLMs are perfect for this and thus a great tool for finding commonÂ ground.

On AI andÂ tools:

  1. The most important thing, I think, that most people in knowledge work should be doing is learning to vibe code. Vibe code anything: a diary, a picture book for your mum, a fan page for your local farm. Anything. Itâ€™s not about learning to code, but rather appreciating how much more we could do with machines than before. This is what I mean about the generalist product manager: being able to prototype, test, and build without being held back by technical constraints. I was able to relaunch my website in a fraction of the time it took me years ago, adding interactive effects and custom graphics that would have taken weeks before. I could finally create a website that feels like me: not only a record of things Iâ€™ve done, but also a place for experiments like a mini social media feed, all without the long nights solving silly problems like deployÂ configs.
  2. Learn to work creatively with LLMs in this order of importance: combinational, exploratory, andÂ novel.
  3. If you let AI do all the writing and planning without understanding the thinking behind it, youâ€™ll lose connection to the outcome. The key is maintaining ownership: can you defend the ideas, explain the reasoning, and adapt the direction mid-process? If yes, youâ€™re using the tool. If not, the tool is using you. Like I said at the start: the danger is delegation turning into abdication.
  4. When working without AI, teams outperformed individuals by a significant amount, and teams working with AI outperformed everything else. (Research source)

On leadership and politics:

  1. Aligning the goals of many people begins with understanding what a good outcome looks like for each of them. This was my biggest learning from bringing together groups with very different approaches to product development.
  2. Paranoia grows with success. I suspect thatâ€™s natural, as you have more to lose, and now you are exposed to far more signals. Keep an eye on it and always be prepared to lose something with the hope of gaining more inÂ return.
  3. You need to learn to love politics, and you also need to understand that politics gets more childish the higher you go up in the organisation.
  4. Sometimes you need to just call out the mood in the room. That we have gone off track, that there is tension, that we need to take a moment to step back. To do this well, ask a question rather than declare it: â€œAre we still aligned on our goals here?â€ invites reflection better than â€œWeâ€™ve lost sight of ourÂ goals.â€

On building and creating:

  1. Donâ€™t build a prototype with the goal of making a solution. Prototypes are best used as questions, notÂ answers.
  2. Thoughtless thinking is a state we should all strive for. Henrik Karlssonâ€™s â€œWhen Is It Better to Think Without Words?â€ explores this beautifully: how our most profound thinking often happens in a pre-verbal state, before weâ€™ve forced our thoughts into the constraints of language. This is the slow, deliberate thinking I mentioned earlier: the kind that gets harder to access as our tools getÂ faster.
  3. Three intelligences: human, artificial, and community.
  4. To do the most important things, you have to say no a lot and disappoint many people, even without a complete plan, even without fully understanding why, in the hope that the space created will be filled with something more valuable.
  5. So much of what is worth doing requires an almost irrational commitment to pushing through pain that would break mostÂ people.
  6. You win either by climbing the mountain ahead of you or building one beneathÂ you.
  7. A great work emerges from an invisible ecology of lesserÂ works.
  8. Sometimes you just need to build a faster horse. There ainâ€™t no shame in admitting that. Spotify was just the faster horse in a world ofÂ iTunes.

On life and perspective:

  1. Experience is what you get when you donâ€™t get what youÂ want.
  2. Strengths and weaknesses are often two sides of the sameÂ coin.
  3. The older I get, the more I realise there arenâ€™t a lot of people who are stupid, but there are allot of people who are incurious. In many ways, I canâ€™t blame them. Social media continually weaponises our curiosity againstÂ us.

On friendship:

  1. When having a party, invite a few close friends to come 30â€“60 minutes early to set up and hang out with you. Those moments before everyone arrives, when youâ€™re just arranging chairs and testing the speaker system, are often more valuable than the party itself. Uriâ€™s â€œ21 Facts About Throwing Good Partiesâ€ captures this wisdom: parties succeed not through perfect execution but through creating the conditions for genuine connection. Like the moon ceremonies and tarot, itâ€™s about creating space for people to witness eachÂ other.
  2. We are biologically wired to return favours, even unearned ones. This works both ways: be mindful of what you accept and what youÂ give.

In theÂ future:

  1. Image generation models have reached a tipping point this year. The most recent models can perform amazing style transfer and contextual image transformations, and they can now reliably produce text with context. I foresee an explosion in visual learning aids and exploration next year. When designing Christmas cards this year or a t-shirt design for LeapSpace, I could layer so much more information: aggregating all my experiences from the year into a symbol-rich card, or blending the most important scientific discoveries with my love of 2001: A Space Odyssey and our product logo. Itâ€™s not just about generating images anymore; itâ€™s about encoding meaning and narrative visually. The same way I encoded narrative into those Sonic songs: remixing what you love through your ownÂ lens.
  2. Iâ€™ve started getting more sophisticated with using AI in different work environments. Using IDEs like Cursor, Iâ€™ve set up folders of documents with custom instructions on how to interact with and retrieve them to help make informed decisions, answer questions, or continue building my knowledge base. Itâ€™s still early, but I really like this idea of the working directory knowledge base that grows with you and is managed byÂ AI.
  3. World models look super interesting. For those unfamiliar, world models are AI systems that build internal representations of their environment, allowing them to predict outcomes and reason about their surroundings. Recent research argues they should develop structured, adaptive representations similar to how young children intuitively learn about the world. Google DeepMindâ€™s Genie 3 even has this awesome visual and interactive version, generating dynamic, navigable worlds at 24 fps with real-time interaction. I can imagine that when they get more consistent, do text really well, are easily promptable and can do style transfer and brand consistency, theyâ€™ll be incredible for games and entertainment.
  4. What hits me is this idea of having simulated environments for our best ideas. It doesnâ€™t have to be a high-fidelity environment necessarily, but one with a set of parameters that can be controlled, understood, and evolve. I often think of the Creature pets from Lionheadâ€™s Black and White game from the 2000s: this was, at the time, state-of-the-art AI in a game of all things! Your behaviour towards the creature, if you treated it nicely or poorly, would directly impact its behaviour and personality towards itself, your villagers and the world around it. This was all part of a more complex system for the creatures, which was also influenced by other factors, such as the skills they were taught, the food they ate, and the events that shaped their lives. All of it, effectively, a bunch of parameters that the game would adjust based on your actions. Treat your creature poorly, punish it in confusing ways and not feed it, over time it will become sickly and cowardly. I often think about this and how modelling a system like that could be a template for working with increasingly complex AIs. That, rather than prompting with instructions and context, we were to give it personality traits and, in addition to collecting memories, adjust those parameters to provide context over time. Itâ€™s a different way of thinking about AI interaction: not as tool use, but as relationship building.

Travel and discoveries:

  1. After seeing one of my favourite shirts ruined on a sweaty 12-hour flight to Tokyo, I discovered Mujiâ€™s undershirts. Now essential for both comfort and confidence (no under arm stains for me), and keeping my nicest shirts safe! Means slightly less washing too: topÂ tip.
  2. The two-phone travel strategy for China: carry one phone for all the Chinese apps and a second to translate the screen of your primary phone. Chinese apps are built with a completely opposite philosophy to the Westâ€™s simplicity, dense with options and configurations. But what struck me most was the gamification of everything. From the potential to win a free Luckin Coffee to getting a random discount on your subway fare. Itâ€™s so alien and different, as if youâ€™re encouraged to participate in the economy with the hope of winning. Every transaction becomes a tiny lottery. Fascinating from a design perspective, maddening from a userÂ one.
  3. If you love hot springs, you need to visit Beitou in Taipei. Most people never visit Taiwan, but if youâ€™re a hot spring lover, this place is absolutely worth theÂ trip.
  4. A country can be in economic decline, but that doesnâ€™t necessarily mean it canâ€™t be graceful. Japan is a master atÂ this.
  5. Comics over anime. I got really tired of watching most things and found myself returning to source material: One Punch Man, Dragon Ball, Death Note, BLAME!, and The Invincible. The Sonic the Comic podcast was a surprisingly detailed hit of nostalgia. Same Sonic that inspired those AI-generated songs I mentioned: everything connects back to what we lovedÂ first.
  6. The Trimui Brick Hammer became my new favourite toy this year. A retro gaming handheld that plays SNES, GBA, PS1, even some Dreamcast and N64 games, all in a compact metal body that feels far more premium than its cost. Perfect for train commutes, flights, and, more importantly, for disconnecting from my phone for all my entertainment. I even installed a custom OS on it, so itâ€™s also now myÂ iPod.
  7. The Bellroy Venture Ready Pack 26L has become the greatest bag Iâ€™ve ever had. Sometimes you just find that perfect piece of gear that fits exactly how you move through theÂ world.
  8. The new iPhone earned its place for two reasons: the orange colour (finally, some personality in tech) and insane all-day batteryÂ life.

On health and awareness:

  1. At the start of the year, I was plagued by sickness until February. It was just a really bad cold/virus, but it encouraged me to finally get some blood tests done as a checklist. I saw a few things I didnâ€™t like, but especially concerning low vitamin D and calcium levels. That event finally encouraged me to optimise my nutrition. Ten months later, an updated blood test shows me things are going in the right direction, and I feel reallyÂ good.
  2. The Oura ring helped me get a handle on how stressed I am at any given time. I started strong with silent retreats and meditation, but didnâ€™t keep that up. However, just recognising the stress has been useful. Attention to whatâ€™s happening in your own body is as important as attention to yourÂ work.
  3. Using foam rollers has brought me so much back relief after months of deskÂ work.
  4. The Ordinaryâ€™s balancing and clarifying serum completely transformed my skincare routine. Simple discoveries made a huge difference.

Borrowed wisdom thatÂ stuck:

  1. â€œIf nothing interrupts you, you are not living; you are a screensaver.â€
  2. â€œFear is the greatest trick your enemies can play on you. Respect fear, but never give into it.â€ Timothy Snyderâ€™s â€œOn Tyranny: Twenty Lessons from the Twentieth Centuryâ€ remains essential reading on how fear becomes the primary tool of manipulation, and why refusing to submit to it is an act of resistance.
  3. â€œBig tech like to see themselves invested in spreading knowledge and curiosity, but most of them prosper when spreading fear and stupidity.â€ The weaponisation of curiosity I keep coming backÂ to.
  4. â€œCollecting is our desire to create a system that competes with the destructiveness of timeÂ itself.â€
  5. â€œYou craft your most authentic self by encountering the ways others have done so themselves.â€
  6. â€œA dark infinity swallowed up our lights.â€: David RoseÂ (source)
  7. â€œPeople like you more when you are working towards something, not when you have it.â€:Â Drake
  8. Glamour offers a promise of escape and transformation.
  9. After water, sand is the second-most-used material in theÂ world.

Reading that shaped my thinking:

Edward Packardâ€™s â€œNine Things I Learned in Ninety Yearsâ€ offers the kind of wisdom that only comes from a life fully lived. And â€œThe Populist Phantomâ€ helped me understand why so many people now describe themselves as disconnected from traditional institutions: sometimes what looks like populism is just people responding rationally to systems that have stopped servingÂ them.

Have a brilliant 2026, everyone.

title: A UX Carol
text:
A UX Carol

A UXÂ carol

It was Christmas Eve, 2025, and like any other day, Ulysses Xavier was doom-scrolling LinkedIn.

It was Christmas Eve, 2025, and like any other day, Ulysses Xavier was doom-scrolling LinkedIn.

Ulysses was a UX designerâ€Šâ€”â€Šor a â€œProduct Designer,â€ or maybe a â€œDigital Experience Architect,â€ or a â€œProduct Experience Manager,â€ depending on which day you asked him. Currently, however, he felt more like a Figma monkey. He sat in his Scandinavian designer chair, bathed in the orangey light of a dual-monitor setup (because you gotta filter out that blue light), reading yet another hot take about how AI had rendered his so-called careerâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhich was kind of a joke, anywayâ€Šâ€”â€Šobsolete.

â€œBah,â€ Ulysses muttered, quickly archiving yet another generic rejection email from a job application. â€œHumbug.â€

He closed his eyes, wishing for the good old times when designers did all the user research and customer journeys by themselves. When he opened them, his MacBook and monitors were gone and his Spotify playlist â€œCoffee Shop Background Noisesâ€ replaced by the screeching, static-filled sound of a 28.8k modem connecting to the internet.

The First of the ThreeÂ Spirits

Standing before him was an ethereal, slightly translucent figure dressed in flannel and holding a copy of HTML forÂ Dummies.

â€œI am the Ghost of UX Past,â€ the figure said, its voice crackling like a 32-kbps RealAudio. â€œCome withÂ me.â€

Suddenly, Ulysses was back in 1995. He saw an attic. A solitary figure sat hunched over a CRT monitor, coding in what looked like a very old-school Apple Notes, typing on a keyboard that seemed way too clunky andÂ loud.

â€œIs thatÂ ... a developer?â€ UlyssesÂ asked.

â€œNo,â€ the Ghost corrected. â€œThat is Max. Heâ€™s whatâ€™s called a webmaster. In this era, there are no silos. He designs the page, writes the HTML, configures the server, and crops the JPEGs in Photoshop. Heâ€™s like a general contractor of theÂ web.â€â€‹Â¹

Ulysses watched Max struggle. He was using invisible tables for layout because CSS didnâ€™t really exist yet.Â² He was embedding headers as images because there were only a handful of fonts like Times New Roman and Courier available.Â³ It looked like a horrible messÂ â€¦ and painful.â€‹

â€œIt looks terrible,â€ Ulysses whispered, eyeing a blinking hitÂ counter.

â€œItâ€™s foundational,â€ the Ghost retorted. â€œThere is nothing like â€˜user experienceâ€™ yetâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDon Norman has only started coining the term at Apple recently.â´ But look at the ownership. Look at the freedom. There are no stakeholders blocking tickets. Thereâ€™s just the creator and the user. Itâ€™s chaotic, yes. But itâ€™s pure creative problem solvingÂ â€¦ well, maybe more creative than solving, to beÂ fair.â€â€‹

â€œWhat is he using?â€ Ulysses asked. The ghost put a hand on his shoulder: â€œItâ€™s called Notepad.â€

Ulysses realized something. The constraints of the pastâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe technical limits, the lack of toolsâ€Šâ€”â€Šforced immense creativity, even if the pages often seemed ugly. But these people werenâ€™t just pushing (ugly) pixels; they were actually wrestling a giantÂ squid.â€‹

The Second of the ThreeÂ Spirits

The scene dissolved into a sterile, open-plan office. Ulysses was sitting at a desk that looked like it rather belonged in a hospital. He noticed that on his monitor, there was a Zoom call with 45 participants.

â€œAm IÂ â€¦ in a Zoom callÂ â€¦ in an office?Â Why?â€

â€œThatâ€™s the exact question I ask myself everydayÂ â€¦ Iâ€™m the Ghost of UX Present, by the way,â€ sighed a weary figure who had appeared at his side, wearing a hoodie and looking noticeably burnedÂ out.

Ulysses looked around in confusion. He saw hundreds of designers churning out high-fidelity mockups in Figma, moving pixels by 4px increments. He saw their anxiety as Slack channels quickly filled with requests from stakeholders and management.

A couple of desks down, one of the designers was just laid off by his manager, â€œbecause revenue is bad and we have AI now to saveÂ costs.â€

â€œLook at them,â€ the Ghost gestured. â€œThey are terrified.â€

Where the Ghost had gestured, Ulysses now saw analytics dashboards floating in the air like holographic projections. He couldnâ€™t identify all the numbers, because they seemed to be using Liquid Glass, but he saw the more than 250,000 tech layoffs from 2023.âµ He saw the job market flooded with bootcamp graduates who had been promised secure and high-paying UXÂ jobs.â€‹â¶

â€œThey feel like assembly line workers,â€ Ulysses said, recognizing the feeling. â€œFigma monkeys.â€â·

â€œPrecisely,â€ the Ghost nodded. â€œThey see product managers doing user research and creating wireframes. They see AI generating layouts faster than they can think. They are fighting for a seat at the table, but once they get there, they just take orders.â€â€‹â¸

The Ghost showed him a designer arguing with a stakeholder. The designer wanted to do discovery research; the stakeholder just wanted the screens done byÂ Friday.

â€œWe have become obsessed with the artifacts of design,â€ the Ghost said sadly. â€œScreens. Flows. Wireframes. We forgot that our job isnâ€™t to make files. Itâ€™s to ensure the product works for the user. And because we act like factory workers, we are surprised when business treats us like a cost center to be optimized.â€â€‹

Ulysses felt a pit in his stomach. â€œIs this it? Is this how it ends? Replaced by AI, apathy, and alienation?â€

The Last of theÂ Spirits

The Zoom call and the office around it faded. Ulysses found himself in a quiet, sunlit room. There were no screens. No keyboards. Just people talking, gesturing, and collaborating. All of them were wearing tags: Human-Centered Product Manager, Interaction Systems Architect, Behavioral Product Strategist, Experience Integration Lead, and Cognitive Systems Engineer.

A tall, calm figure stood there. This Ghost didnâ€™t look scary. It lookedÂ â€¦ Ulysses didnâ€™t know how exactly, but maybe something like empowered?!

â€œI know what you think. Youâ€™ve looked at the job titles and now you think UX is dead,â€ the Ghost said. â€œBut you are confusing the title with the discipline. We are all designers in one way or the other. I used to be called a â€˜UX designer,â€™ but that was a long timeÂ ago.â€

â€œWhere are the screens?â€ Ulysses asked, looking for aÂ laptop.

â€œGone,â€ the Ghost smiled. â€œOr rather, the ideas of â€˜screensâ€™ and â€˜average usersâ€™ are gone. Why would we design one interface on just 5 different screens, but for millions of users? The â€˜averageâ€™ user never existedÂ anyway.â€

The Ghost waved a hand, and Ulysses saw a vision of theÂ future:

1. The End of the Screen (as we knowÂ it)

â€œPeople here donâ€™t draw pages,â€ the Ghost explained. â€œThey define systems and constraints. They design components and the rules that govern themâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€˜The header is always top,â€™ â€˜Component A prioritizes over Component B,â€™ and so on. An AI takes those components and rules and generates hyper-personalized interfaces for every single user, adapted to their specific device and context.â€

2. The Designer asÂ Educator

Ulysses saw a Human-Centered Product Manager sitting with a Behavioral Product Strategist and a Cognitive Systems Engineer in what seemed to be a very intensive coaching session. â€œWe stopped fighting the inevitable,â€ the Ghost said. â€œWe embraced the fact that stakeholders, engineers, and product managers wantâ€Šâ€”â€Šand needâ€Šâ€”â€Što be involved in design. So we became force multipliers. We realized thatâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust like with researchâ€”you canâ€™t prevent â€˜non-designersâ€™ from designing. But they need support and guidance to ensure the best outcome for the user. Now, our job is to empower everyone to solve their problems with the right design methods, so we can focus on the really wicked stuff and strategy. Oh, and you of course noticed already, but we all got new titles and merged with other disciplines, because in the end, everything is design and nobody understood UX correctly, anyway.â€â€‹

3. The Death of the â€œMonkeyÂ Workerâ€

â€œBut what about AI?â€ Ulysses asked. â€œDid it replace us?â€
â€œObviously not. It replaced the monkey workers,â€ the Ghost answered firmly. â€œIt replaced the rote production of UI assets. But it couldnâ€™t replace the creative problem solving. Real designers arenâ€™t monkey workers. They are strategic partners. The term â€˜UX Designerâ€™ might have vanished from job descriptions, merged into Product or Engineering, but the practice of UX is more vital than ever. Because one thing is for sure: thereâ€™ll always be users, and thereâ€™ll always be experiences.â€

The End ofÂ It
